headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Best Buy's fourth quarter fiscal 2016 earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for playback, and will be available approximately by 11:00 a.m.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Best Buy's fourth quarter fiscal 2016 earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for playback, and will be available approximately by 11:00 a.m. Eastern Time today. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to attend the conference over to Mollie O'Brien, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you. Joining me on the call today are Hubert Joly, our Chairman and CEO; and Sharon McCollam, our CAO and CFO.This morning's conference call must be considered in conjunction with the earnings press release we issued this morning
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you. Joining me on the call today are Hubert Joly, our Chairman and CEO; and Sharon McCollam, our CAO and CFO.
This morning's conference call must be considered in conjunction with the earnings press release we issued this morning. Today's release and conference call both contain non-GAAP financial measures that exclude the impact of certain business events. These non-GAAP financial measures are provided to facilitate meaningful year-over-year comparisons, which should not be considered superior to, as a substitute for and should be read in conjunction with the GAAP financial of the period. Reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures and an explanation of why these non-GAAP financial measures are useful can be found in this morning's earnings release.
Today's earnings release and conference call also include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements address the financial conditions, results of operations, business initiatives, growth plans, operational investments, prospects of the company, and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from such a forward-looking statements. Please refer to the company's current earnings release and SEC filings for more information on these risks and uncertainties. The company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances that may arise after the date of this call.
In today's earnings release and conference call, we refer to consumer electronics industry trends. The consumer-electronics industry, as defined and tracked by The NPD Group, includes: TVs; desktop and notebook computers; tablets, not including Kindle; digital imaging; and other categories.  Sales of these products represent approximately 65% [ph] of our Domestic revenue. It does not include mobile phones, appliances, services, gaming, Apple Watch, movies or summa.
Final housekeeping item before I turn the call over to Hubert. Beginning in January fiscal '17, we will no longer issue an interim holiday press release due to the increasing significant month of January our overall fourth quarter financial [indiscernible  I will now turn the call over to Hubert.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I will begin today with a review of our fourth quarter and annual performance, and then provide an overview of the next phase of our Renew Blue strategy. We will then turn the call to Sharon for additi
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I will begin today with a review of our fourth quarter and annual performance, and then provide an overview of the next phase of our Renew Blue strategy. We will then turn the call to Sharon for additional details on our quarterly results and commentary on our financial outlook.
From a financial perspective, in the first quarter, we delivered Enterprise revenue of $13.62 billion, improved our non-GAAP operating income rate by 10 basis points to 5.9%, and delivered a better-than-expected non-GAAP EPS of $1.53 versus $1.48 last year. In our Domestic business, we exceeded our bottom line expectations due to a well executed holiday plan, a disciplined promotional strategy, better recovery on returns and clearance product and strong expense management. 
While Domestic revenue declined 1.5%, it was against a backdrop where the NPD reported categories were down 5.1%. Strong performance in health and wearables, home theater and appliances was more than offset by softness in the mobile phone category and continued declines in tablets. In addition, we continue to significant growth in the online channel with e-commerce revenue increasing nearly 14% to 15.6% of total Domestic revenue. In the International business, our performance was better than expected on the top and bottom lines, while revenue declined at 26.2% due to the expected impacts of foreign currency and store closures in Canada. Revenue retention from the brand consolidation continued to exceed our expectations. This high retention in addition to a more effective promotional strategy, drove a 30-basis-point increase in the International non-GAAP operating income rate to 4.7%. 
On a full year basis, fiscal 2016 marks the second year in a row we increased our Domestic revenue and expended our operating margin. We also continued to do to make significant progress against our Renew Blue strategy. So during the year, we continue to gain share in appliances in nearly all of our traditional consumer-electronics categories. We grew Domestic online revenue 13% to over $4 billion or 11% of total Domestic revenue. We increased our Net Promoter Score by over 300 basis points. We continue to improve our employee engagement scores and decreased employee turnover. We deepened our partnerships with top tech companies in the world. We delivered $150 million against our $400 million Renew Blue Phase 2 cost reduction and gross profit optimization program. We consolidated brands and embarked on a significant transformation in Canada, including the closure of 68 stores. And finally, in 1 year, we returned $1.5 billion in cash to our shareholders, including $1 billion in share repurchases, which was originally planned to be completed over 3 years.
This performance is the direct result of the execution of our Renew Blue strategy and the hard work, dedication and customer focus on the part of all of our associates. I am proud to recognize them publicly this morning.
Turning to fiscal 2017. We are entering the next phase of our Renew Blue strategy. Our purpose from a customers' standpoint is to build a company that does a unique job of helping customers, learn about and enjoy the latest technology. As we begin this next phase, in fiscal 2017, we will execute against the following priorities: Number 1, build and our strong industry position in multi-channel capabilities to drive the existing business; number 2, drive cost reduction and efficiency; and number 3, advance key initiatives to drive future growth and differentiation.
So our first priority is to build on our strong industry position and multi-channel capabilities to drive the existing business, more specifically, we will implement a number of initiatives across merchandising, marketing, digital, chores services and supply chain. For example, in home theater, we will build on the superior customer experience we've created in partnership with our key vendors, and leverage the strength of our market-leading share in 4K and large-screen televisions. We will also add 5 Magnolia Design Centers stores-within-a-store, bringing our total to 84 by year end. 
In appliances, we expect to continue to grow our market share by adding an incremental 27 Pacific Kitchen & Home stores-within-a-store, bringing our total to 203 at year-end, and by leveraging the new vendor appliance experiences that we launched in Q3 of last year.  Additionally, we expect to see incremental growth from our enhanced delivery and installation offerings, which are driving high conversion and material improvements in NPS, Net Promoter Score.
In Connected Home, we will continue to increase our assortment in emerging categories, including security, writing and video monitoring, expand our in-store presentation, and leverage our leading position in routers and networking equipment which from the backbone of the Connected Home.
In mobile phones, we will capitalize on the customer experience investments we've communicated late last year with an expectation to drive increased in version, as well as a reduced wait time for our customers. Our strategy is to be an advocate for every phone order by offering the best deal in plans and devices, in partial advice, in clarity and efficiency, we can be a complex process.
In the very short time, we believe high smartphone penetration, combined with low consumer demand for current product offerings, it's depressing the category. But over the course of the year, we believe that more compelling phone launches can fuel renewed growth in the category.
From an online standpoint, we will continue to build out new digital capabilities, prioritizing the customer shopping experience on phones and tablet devices. Examples of recent advances include the successful Q4 launch of Blue Assist, which allows customers to simply shake their device to get live help with products and orders through chat, call and e-mail. For example, its touch ID login, included in our latest mobile app update, and of course, our recently launched Geek Squad app.
In our retail stores, we will continue to drive increased sales proficiency and further leverage our service capabilities. In fiscal 2016, our Blue Shirts and Geek Squad agents contributed significantly to our NPS and market share gains, and we believe that continues to be significant further opportunity to take this competitive advantage to the next level.
And then finally, in our International business, we remain focused on our Canadian transformation. We will continue to invest in our stores and online channel to improve the customer experience and a financial performance.
Our second priority for fiscal 2017 is to reduce costs and drive efficiencies throughout the business. We do see costs is essential for us to be able to fund our investment, build our resilience to product cycle, and increase our profitability over time. Furthermore, based on the -- on current economic factors and softness in the consumer-electronics industry, it is essential that we be proactive on the cost reduction front.  A key element of our approach to achieving this is to simplify our business processes to simultaneously improve the customer experience and drive costs down. 
As an example, we have a project focused on reducing the amount of open box appliances we take into our stores by addressing root cause issues. This project has a potential to know the improve the customer experience, but also to drive material savings from lower markdowns, lower transportation costs and better use of labor in our stores and distributions centers.
Are broadly, we aspire to achieve world-class operational levels of performance, defined in terms of quality, service and cost. This focus has to be a way of life, especially given our margin structure and the volatility of our industry.
Last year, we announced a specific cost reduction and gross profit optimization program called Renew Blue Phase 2, with the goal of $400 million of over 3 years, on top of the $1 billion we eliminated as part of Phase 1. Against that goal, in the fiscal 2016, we achieved $150 million, leaving us with $250 million. 
In light of our increased focus on cost and productivity, we believe there are incremental savings that can be achieved above and beyond our current goal which we will update you on as we progress.  Partially offsetting these savings will be our expected future investments in the areas of labor expertise, services pricing and key growth initiatives, which I will discuss in a moment.  In fiscal 2016, these investments totaled approximately $100 million, and we expect a similar level in fiscal 2017 which to be clear, will be funded by our cost savings.
Our third priority is to advance key initiatives to more deeply transform Best Buy in order to drive future growth and differentiation. While there may be short and precious, we continue to believe we operate in an opportunity which environment. The event of the Internet of Things is providing a new technology way that is making Best Buy's operating model increasingly relevant to customers. We are investing to be the leading technology experts which makes it easy to learn about and confidently enjoy the Best Buy. 
In this context, we believe we have ongoing growth opportunities around key product categories as well as from increasing our share of wallet with existing customers, and acquiring new customers within our target segments, who are those of us passionate about technology and need help with it. Capturing these opportunities, we require that we do the following: Number 1, develop and bring to market curated solution driven merchandise to solve key customer problems, in particular, in new growth areas and; number 2, ensure we have an inspirational and educational sales approach across all sales channels that helps customers understand the value that technology can create for them; number 3, help customers unleash responsible from their technology; and number 4, provide customers with ongoing convenient purchase support.  Inherent in all of this is the desire to build a stronger ongoing relationship with our customers.
Now our services capabilities in Geek Squad are key building blocks of this strategy. We understand that we've discussed service-related opportunities many times in the past. And while it is not visible in our services top line results today, we are, in fact, making progress to bring these opportunities to life. To do so, we've had to spend time in the last 2 years fixing many aspects of our traditional warranty and repair businesses. We've also had to adjust our pricing in warranty business. We are seeing the results of our efforts through substantial increases in Net Promoter Score's, higher total customer interactions and from a financial point of view, the periodic profit-sharing payments we earned this year.  We are also beginning to see improved attach rates as we enter fiscal 2017.
Building on this, we will continue our work to improve the customer experience and enhance our service offering and capabilities in support of our mission to help customers learn about and enjoy the latest tech. 
While we are energized with a potential of this opportunity, the work necessary to capture it, it takes time. Thus, fiscal 2017 will be another year of gradual and incremental improvement, with more meaningful results expected in fiscal 2018.
Now before I turn the call over to Sharon, I'd like to provide some thoughts about our fiscal 2017 outlook and return of capital plan. So in summary, Best Buy is a specialty retailer that excels in an industry characterized by product innovation cycles. We are undeterred by this fact, as we believe there will always be technology innovation and an imperative is that in these cycles, we continue to deliver superior execution against what's in recognizing that the cycles any point in time.
In fiscal 2017, we are focused on continue to build in our foundation to both drive and capitalize on these technology cycles. In parallel, we are focused key initiatives that we discussed today that we believe will result in stickier relationship with our customers, provide profitable revenue even during down cycles, and continue to create long-term shareholder value.
More over time as the fruits of these key initiatives materialize, we expect to accelerate our revenue and operating income growth by taking advantage of opportunities provided by ongoing technology innovation and the need to customers have for help.
In the short term, we will be characterized by our strong cash flow generating capabilities in our intent to regularly return excess free cash flow to shareholders. 
From a financial outlook perspective for fiscal 2017, based on current industry dynamics and how we see the various product cycles playing out in our Domestic business, we are expecting revenue declines in the first half followed by growth in the back half. We also expect that our strong execution in operational capabilities will allow us to continue to gain market share. In this context, we are targeting flat Domestic revenue for the full year due to continued growth in appliances, connected home and home theater, in particular, but recognize that being flat will be challenging without the strong mobile cycle, and improvements in the NPD reported categories overall. 
Despite the soft line -- the soft top line environment, we will target flattish operating income, including the lapping of the significant periodic profit-sharing benefits from our services client portfolio that we earned in fiscal 2016.
A key element to achieve this will be the delivery of our cost reduction and gross profit optimization initiatives. In addition, we intend to reward our shareholders by being a premium dividend payer, and increasing our earnings per share through ongoing share repurchases. I would now like to talk about our fiscal 2017 return of capital plan. 
After 3 consecutive years of strong cash flow generation in the Renew Blue, we believe that now is an ideal time to provide a view of our long-term capital allocation strategy. This strategy is based on our strong cash position today and our ongoing confidence in our future cash flow generation.
At the core of this strategy is our intent to: First, fund our operations and growth and investments, including potential acquisitions; and then to return the remaining excess free cash flow to our shareholders over time through dividends and share repurchases while maintaining investment-grade credit metrics. This strategy targets the return of excess free cash flow to shareholders through a 35% to 45% non-GAAP dividend payout ratio, and regular share repurchases with the minimum annual expectation of offsetting dilution from equity compensation.
So in line with this strategy, our fiscal 2017 return of capital plan includes: Number 1, the 22% increase in the regular quarterly dividend to $0.28 per share; number 2, the intent to repurchase $1 billion worth of shares over the next 2 years; and number 3, a special dividend of $0.45 per share or approximately $145 million.
This is in addition to the $1.5 billion in cash we returned to shareholders in fiscal 2016. I will now turn the call over to Sharon to discuss the details of our fourth quarter financials and our Q1 fiscal '17 guidance.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hubert, and good morning, everyone. Before I talk about our fourth quarter results versus last year, I would like to talk about them versus the expectations we shared with you in our holiday sales release.Enterprise revenue of $13.6 billion w
componenttext:
Thank you, Hubert, and good morning, everyone. Before I talk about our fourth quarter results versus last year, I would like to talk about them versus the expectations we shared with you in our holiday sales release.
Enterprise revenue of $13.6 billion was in line with expectations. Our non-GAAP operating income rate of 5.9%, however, exceeded our expectations due to better-than-expected profitability in both our Domestic and International businesses driven by a more affected, disciplined promotional strategy, better recovery on returned and clearance products, and an approximate $0.02 of additionally EPS from the periodic profit-sharing benefit from our externally managed extended service plan portfolio.
Additionally, our non-GAAP effective income tax rate was 34%, resulting in an incremental $0.02 of EPS versus expectations. I will now talk about our fourth quarter results versus last year.
Enterprise revenue declined 4.1% to $13.6 billion, primarily due to a 1.8% comparable sales decline in the Domestic business, and negative foreign currency impact of approximately 140 basis points, and the negative impact of Canadian store closures. 
Enterprise non-GAAP diluted EPS increased $0.05 or 3% to $1.53. This increase was primarily driven by the service periodic profit-sharing benefit of $0.19, and a share repurchase benefit of $0.06. These benefits were partially offset by Domestic revenue declines in the mobile phone, tablet and digital imaging categories and the expected $0.03 negative impact from the Canadian brand consolidation.
In our Domestic segment, revenue decreased 1.5% to $12.5 billion. This decline was primarily driven by a comparable sales decline of 1.8%, excluding the estimated 10 basis point benefit associated with installment billing and the loss of revenue from 13 large format and 17 small format Best Buy mobile store closures. These declines were partially offset by the 10-basis-point benefit associated with installment billing and the approximate 80 basis points services periodic profit-sharing benefits, which is not included in our comparable sales calculation.
From a merchandising perspective, comparable sales growth in health and wearables, home theater and major appliances was more than offset by a significant declines and mobile phones, tablets, digital imaging and services. 
In services, comparable revenue declined 11.9% due to investments in services pricing and the ongoing reduction of repair revenue driven by lower frequency and severity of claims on extended warranty.
In our International segment, revenue declined 26.2% to $1.1 billion due to a negative foreign currency impact of approximately 1,350 basis points, the loss of revenue associated with closed stores as part of the Canadian brand consolidation and the ongoing softness in the Canadian economy and consumer electronics industry.
Turning now to gross profit. The Enterprise non-GAAP gross profit rate increased 30 basis points to 21.6%. The Domestic non-GAAP gross profit rate increased 40 basis points to 21.6%. This increase was primarily due to a 65-basis-point impact from the services periodic profit-sharing benefit and the improved rates in the mobile and computing categories, primarily due to a more disciplined promotional strategy. These increases were partially offset by an increased mix of lower margin wearable devices, a decreased mix of higher-margin digital imaging products, a lower rate in televisions driven by a decline in average selling prices and higher distribution costs and our investments in services pricing.
The International non-GAAP gross profit rate increased 10 basis points to 21.8%. This increase was primarily driven by higher year-over-year gross profit rates in both Canada and Mexico due to a more disciplined promotional strategy.
Now turning to SG&A. Enterprise-level non-GAAP SG&A was $2.1 billion or 15.7% of revenue, a decrease of $68 million, but an increase of 20 basis points. Domestic non-GAAP SG&A was $1.95 billion or 15.6% of revenue, and was nearly flat in dollars  year-over-year as investments in future growth initiatives and lower vendor funding being recorded as an offset to SG&A were offset by the flow of Renew Blue Phase 2 cost reductions and lower incentive compensation.
From a rate perspective, non-GAAP SG&A increased 30 basis points, primarily driven by year-over-year sales deleverage.
International non-GAAP SG&A was $192 million or 17.2% of revenue, a decrease of $70 million or 10 basis points. This decrease was primarily driven by the elimination of expenses associated with the Canadian brand consolidation and the positive impact of foreign exchange rates. 
Specific to the Canadian brand consolidation, we incurred non-GAAP diluted EPS impact of negative $0.03 in the fourth quarter and negative $0.07 for fiscal 2016. These impacts were lower than expected due to higher sales retention from closed stores, a more discipline promotional strategy and our decision to transform only a limited number of stores this year in order to pilot results.
In Q1 of fiscal '17, Canada will still be lopping 68 of its store closures last year, and facing ongoing foreign currency in Canadian economic headwinds. As such, in Q1, we expect International revenues to decline 15% to 20%. 
Beginning in the second quarter and through the balance of the year, while currency and economic headwinds will continue to be a challenge, in constant currency, the International business is expected to be near flat on both the top and bottom line.
From a cash flow perspective, and a full year basis, capital expenditures totaled $649 million, and we returned $1.5 billion in cash to our shareholders. 
In working capital, our decision to bring holiday inventory in early as well as insuperable moving into Q1 fiscal '17 resulted in a total every longer and hiring costs payable prior to year-end. This created a timing issue, which resulted in our ratio of accounts payable to inventory being lower at year end than last year. As we look forward to next year, capital expenditures are expected to be in the range of the $650 million to $700 million, and the accounts payable to inventory ratio is expected to increase.
I would now like to talk about our Q1 financial guidance. In the Domestic business, we believe that the softness that we saw in the NPD tracked categories and mobile phones will continue into Q1. We also believe that in the International business, revenue will be down by approximately 15% to 20% due to ongoing impacts of foreign currency and the Canadian brand consolidation which was not executed until late March of 2015.  With that backdrop, we are expecting Enterprise revenue in the range of $8.25 billion to $8.35 billion, and Enterprise comparable sales in the range of negative 1% to negative 2%, primarily driven by continued softness in the mobile and tablet categories.
Our non-GAAP effective income tax rate is expected to be in the range of 39% to 39.5%, and our not Q1 I'm diluted earnings per share is expected the be the range of $0.31 to $0.35, assuming a diluted weighted average share count of approximately 326 million.
I would now like to turn the call over to the operator for questions.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll first go to Kate McShane with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll first go to Kate McShane with Citi.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question today is focused on the return of capital plan that you outlined. Just 2 questions around that. One, can you explain to us this -- the thinking behind in the special dividend versus just increasing a regular dividend or doing more share buybac
componenttext: My question today is focused on the return of capital plan that you outlined. Just 2 questions around that. One, can you explain to us this -- the thinking behind in the special dividend versus just increasing a regular dividend or doing more share buyback with that cash? And could you remind us how you're thinking about possible acquisitions and how that can enhance Best Buy over the long term?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Kate. On the special dividend, very similar to last year, we had these legal settlements that are from prior years and they're substantial. You see them when you look at the GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliations. And last year, we returned that thr
componenttext: Absolutely, Kate. On the special dividend, very similar to last year, we had these legal settlements that are from prior years and they're substantial. You see them when you look at the GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliations. And last year, we returned that through the special dividend to our shareholders. In addition to that, we had asset disposal. One was the sale of Europe last year, and then we have some small entities that we sold this year. And as those were assets that were a part of the existing core base of our business, we think it's giving that cash back to our existing shareholders. It makes sense that it's an elegant way to get cash back to our shareholders.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Kate, to your question about our acquisitions, we do mention acquisitions in the press release, and I mentioned them in my prepared remarks. So in answer to your question, the framework is as follows: We have a clear mission which is to -- be  obvious
componenttext: And Kate, to your question about our acquisitions, we do mention acquisitions in the press release, and I mentioned them in my prepared remarks. So in answer to your question, the framework is as follows: We have a clear mission which is to -- be  obvious do this unique job of helping customers learn about and enjoy technology. Acquisitions would be helpful in as much as they bring us capabilities to accelerate our transformation in this direction, that's the first criteria. And of course, the second important criteria as you would appreciate, is to be financially accretive all the time. So that's the backdrop of that, nothing imminent, but we thought it was appropriate to divulge to you this morning.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we go to Dan Binder with Jefferies.
componenttext: Next, we go to Dan Binder with Jefferies.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: From an execution standpoint, it seems that you doing everything you should, and you don't have a lot of control over the cycles. But I did want to focus a little bit on the cycles for a minute, and get your view on things like virtual reality, what's in
componenttext: From an execution standpoint, it seems that you doing everything you should, and you don't have a lot of control over the cycles. But I did want to focus a little bit on the cycles for a minute, and get your view on things like virtual reality, what's in the pipe for mobile that you think is going to turn that business around -- can we get another year out of TV, and where do you think Connected Home starts to hit a -- the sweet spot?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. So talking about the future in this industry is always interesting and let me try to be as helpful as possible. As we look ahead in particular, fiscal '17, the areas where we see key growth opportunities for us, around appliances, where we
componenttext:
Yes, thank you. So talking about the future in this industry is always interesting and let me try to be as helpful as possible. As we look ahead in particular, fiscal '17, the areas where we see key growth opportunities for us, around appliances, where we, as you know, we've had multiple quarters, multiple years now of growth, and that's going to continue to be driven by the housing recovery. Second is connected objects, so around the connected -- the Internet of Things, Connected Home, and then of course, there's the continued TV cycle. The specific categories you talk about, so in particular, virtual reality, we are very sided. We have this promotion. Find a ready disinterested the buying the Galaxy S7, you can preorder now at Best Buy, and you get a free virtual reality gear, and then some additional memory, so great value. Candidly, this is an interesting category. I think it will still be small this year. It may help in the computing category with higher end computers, because you're going to need that computing power.
But it's from a financial standpoint, it's going to be limited. Mobile, I think I'm going to stick to my prepared remarks. It's going to be a function of new products revising the category. And I'm not going to make any forward-looking statement on that particular point. TV is, of course, we've been very excited and performing really well with 4K and large-screen TVs. Our share has been increasing. Of course, like any cycle, it's not going to continue forever, so it's not going to be a strong going forward as it has been from a growth rate standpoint. Connected Home, I think it's an exciting category. Increasingly, it's not just about the security cameras or the smart logs and so forth. Everything in your home is connected, at least in my home. Your smart TV is connected. Your music, your streaming, your home office is connected, gaming is connected. And of course, getting into security, home automation, energy management. And the complexity of this -- if you think about this, with the control layer, the security layer, the networking layer, the access layer, provides a lot of complexity. And so the continued innovation and the complexity creates a big opportunity for us. So we're seeing growth amid comments about the fact that we are increasing the assortments, the presentation and we're voting on our strength in routers and networking. So we'll see continued growth in that growth space of connected objects and the Internet of Things.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Sharon, if I could -- just 1 follow-up on Canada. Think you said operating income flat year-over-year. With the expenses related to the store closings, I thought there was supposed to be a year-over-year swing this year that would be positive. I was w
componenttext: And Sharon, if I could -- just 1 follow-up on Canada. Think you said operating income flat year-over-year. With the expenses related to the store closings, I thought there was supposed to be a year-over-year swing this year that would be positive. I was wondering if you'd just add a little color to that flat operating profit outlook?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Well, first, there's 2 things. One is the impact of foreign currency which has been substantial. Remember, that your -- that averages into the cost of inventory over time. And as that has been prolonged, that will affect them from a gross prof
componenttext: Absolutely. Well, first, there's 2 things. One is the impact of foreign currency which has been substantial. Remember, that your -- that averages into the cost of inventory over time. And as that has been prolonged, that will affect them from a gross profit standpoint. In addition to that, the Canadian economy also has been pretty soft. And we are playing that into our outlook, and making sure that we have accounted for what we think is happening there right now. But we could not be more pleased with the consolidation, the retention rates, the execution that has happened up there. And lastly, there will also be some additional investments next year. But remember, we're saying we're offsetting our investments as a company, but there will be some investments in these new pilot stores that we are working on. And there's disruption when we're approaching that. So that will be another aspect of it. We're not going to be announcing every quarter a impact of the Canadian brand consolidation and these stores. We're going to treated for your much is business as usual. But there is a significant investment, and is this why the CapEx mix here is going up just slightly because that will be higher in Canada.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, just on the cost savings versus offsets. So you saved about $150 million this year. Did you tell us what the investments were? And then what I'm getting at is that over the next 2 years, you quantified $250 million in savings, but $200
componenttext: Two questions. One, just on the cost savings versus offsets. So you saved about $150 million this year. Did you tell us what the investments were? And then what I'm getting at is that over the next 2 years, you quantified $250 million in savings, but $200 million in offsets. So over the course of the 3 years, that $400 million in savings. How much of that should we expect to flow to the bottom line?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Mike. Thank you for your question. An important consideration, thinking about this fiscal '17 is the fact in the we are lapping the periodic payment really to our service portfolio, so that's a meaningful thing. So achieving flattish operating income r
componenttext: So Mike. Thank you for your question. An important consideration, thinking about this fiscal '17 is the fact in the we are lapping the periodic payment really to our service portfolio, so that's a meaningful thing. So achieving flattish operating income rate domestically is made possible by these cost savings and this renewed focus. So the general principle is we're offsetting all of our investments with cost savings and then we're able to lap this periodic payment.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So sort of a net neutral over the 3 years, it sounds like? We if I could ask 1 more question. Just in terms of your stores in the U.S., looks like you closed about 10 of the big box stores in the U.S. I think about 10 in the quarter, 13 for the year
componenttext: Okay. So sort of a net neutral over the 3 years, it sounds like? We if I could ask 1 more question. Just in terms of your stores in the U.S., looks like you closed about 10 of the big box stores in the U.S. I think about 10 in the quarter, 13 for the year. How should we think about that going forward? I know you don't announce share buy -- store closures specifically, but should we expect that to continue to come down? And as part of the question, what are the leases look like in terms of expiration? I think 2015 [ph] was a heavy year for expirations. Can you confirm that?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's -- every year, here on out it, is a big year for expirations. We have well over 100 expirations coming into fiscal '16. And Michael, we will continue to do what we have been doing, which is methodically rationalize the real estate portfolio. The
componenttext: Yes. It's -- every year, here on out it, is a big year for expirations. We have well over 100 expirations coming into fiscal '16. And Michael, we will continue to do what we have been doing, which is methodically rationalize the real estate portfolio. The diligence around about renewals is a substantial if we are renewing. Also, you can see it in the lease disclosure every year, that the term that we're committing to win these leases is shorter, and we will continue to do that to maintain flexibility and the portfolio. But rest assured that we will continue to rationalize as we deem it appropriate. The great news is that the stores that remain in our portfolio, they are performing. The key for us is improving and increasing our retention rates in the U.S. Unlike Canada where the stores were literally in the same parking lot, a mile away, 3 miles away, in the U.S., we never built our portfolio that way. So you can't immediately extract these really strong results from Canada and assume that if we did that in the U.S., it would look exactly the same.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what are the expected transfer rates in the U.S. or the experience in the 13 of those stores you closed this year?
componenttext: So what are the expected transfer rates in the U.S. or the experience in the 13 of those stores you closed this year?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given that publicly, and we don't know yet, obviously, because many of those stores closed the 1st of October. So you won't know until you cycled the full year and we don't actually have, as you know, the last several years, but we closed about
componenttext: We haven't given that publicly, and we don't know yet, obviously, because many of those stores closed the 1st of October. So you won't know until you cycled the full year and we don't actually have, as you know, the last several years, but we closed about 49 stores prior to Hubert and I joining the company. And we won't had a small number of stores since that time that I've actually closed. So from a retention point of view, we're looking at something in the low to mid-30s. And in some of these stores, you would need higher retention rates than that in order to justify the store closures.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Chris, we had quantified the impact of the Super Bowl and obviously, the Super Bowl did move. The one thing to keep in mind just about February is the -- we had substantial store closures this year as a result of the weather situation. So that put a little bit of an offset to that. But we were very -- and we give you the estimate, and we continue to believe that, that is what it's played out to be.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then follow-up on the prior question about at the cycles in the back half outlook. How are you thinking about TV, the TV category as the year progresses from a sales and, I guess, gross profit dollar perspective? And are you expectin
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then follow-up on the prior question about at the cycles in the back half outlook. How are you thinking about TV, the TV category as the year progresses from a sales and, I guess, gross profit dollar perspective? And are you expecting tablets to see any sort of a rebound in the back half as you think about the revenue recovery in the back half?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Chris, good morning. The further out you go, and the more specific the questions are, the harder it is to predict. We -- shared in my prepared remarks our view that in the aggregate for the year, we can be flattish on the top and bottom line standpoi
componenttext: Yes. Chris, good morning. The further out you go, and the more specific the questions are, the harder it is to predict. We -- shared in my prepared remarks our view that in the aggregate for the year, we can be flattish on the top and bottom line standpoint in there. In the U.S., there's going to be a lot of moving pieces. TVs, the cycle has been very strong. We've performed extremely well. We expect to continue to perform and do a great job for our customers. We don't expect the growth rates to remain the same. So this is going to start down. Tablets, I think it's anybody's guess. I think one of the vendors has made forward-looking comments about tablets. I don't know if they have anything to add to this. So we thought it helpful -- and this is the first time we're actually doing this, to provide a full year perspective. So we're thinking a bit of a risk here, and it's a portfolio view, right? And then things will move within that. That's probably the best I can tell you this morning.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, you're targeting flattish operating income next year. You mentioned the CapEx a little bit elevated. Is the flattish operating income notwithstanding that CapEx, is that a reasonable proxy for direction for cash, or are there other items on working
componenttext: First, you're targeting flattish operating income next year. You mentioned the CapEx a little bit elevated. Is the flattish operating income notwithstanding that CapEx, is that a reasonable proxy for direction for cash, or are there other items on working capital that'll go in your favor?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe that from a working capital point of view, as I mentioned, there's accounts payable to inventory ratio. This year was extremely low because of the decisions and the shift of the Super Bowl. Now next year, the Super Bowl will continue to be aroun
componenttext: I believe that from a working capital point of view, as I mentioned, there's accounts payable to inventory ratio. This year was extremely low because of the decisions and the shift of the Super Bowl. Now next year, the Super Bowl will continue to be around the same time. But obviously, we'll be lapping that. So that won't change, but we are the other side of our business, we do expect to be increasing that accounts payable to inventory ratio by year end. So I expect to see a little bit of benefit coming from that.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a follow-up on the services investments. Can you tell us how much of the sales pressure is now self-induced versus -- because of lower prices versus the change in units or attached rate? And can you remind us is there any additional benefit
componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up on the services investments. Can you tell us how much of the sales pressure is now self-induced versus -- because of lower prices versus the change in units or attached rate? And can you remind us is there any additional benefit from the profit-sharing in 2016?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So several questions. The services revenue decline, there's a piece which we've called nonproductive revenue, which is the -- which is driven by the lower frequency and cost severity related to the clients. As a relates to the productive revenue, whi
componenttext: Yes. So several questions. The services revenue decline, there's a piece which we've called nonproductive revenue, which is the -- which is driven by the lower frequency and cost severity related to the clients. As a relates to the productive revenue, which is the one that we care about, the trend is starting to evolve because we have price investment, and then we have provided for you in Q4 and that's going to, of course, carry over into this fiscal year. And it is partially offset by the -- we're seeing -- beginning of an increase in the attach rates. We never expected it -- expect the attach rates to full year offset the price investment. This is an area, frankly, where the elasticity is much lower than on the key hardware categories. But we thought it was the right thing to do from a customers' standpoint as we look ahead. As relates to -- a periodic payment from the warranty portfolio, last year was an exceptional year. And we've disclosed every quarter, the amounts. It was driven by again, the improved performance of our service portfolio, so nothing to be shy about around that. But this was an exceptional year because it was multiple -- it was twice the amounts. Now looking ahead in this fiscal year, we'll get some continued improvement in that business as the improved operational performance, severity and frequency, will carry over -- not so much in the form of periodic payments, but in the form of lower cost charged to the portfolio, not nearly close to the amount of fiscal '16, but some portion. Now what's exciting for us is that we get to lap the party exceptional payment last year, and we're able to do this through the increased focus on cost and efficiency.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Simeon, I just have that Hubert also in his prepared remarks mentioned that as we got towards the Q4, the pricing was in place, et cetera. We did start seeing some upticks in our attach rates in the 1/3 of this business, which was the foundation of th
componenttext: And Simeon, I just have that Hubert also in his prepared remarks mentioned that as we got towards the Q4, the pricing was in place, et cetera. We did start seeing some upticks in our attach rates in the 1/3 of this business, which was the foundation of the investment in the services pricing and the launch of AppleCare, et cetera. So on that side of it, we are pleased with how that is playing out for us from a strategic point of view.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scot Ciccarelli. I think one of the things you talked about as a benefit for this past holiday season was the expectation for improved in-stock levels given the prior year's launch of shift from story. Can you help quantify what the comp impact was that y
componenttext: Scot Ciccarelli. I think one of the things you talked about as a benefit for this past holiday season was the expectation for improved in-stock levels given the prior year's launch of shift from story. Can you help quantify what the comp impact was that you think you experienced from the improved inventory levels? And related to that, are there opportunities to further improve in-stock, or are you kind of where you want to be at this stage?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, Scott. Yes, there is no question that we improved our in-stock levels and what is terrific is that our customers noticed it. This was an area where we received recognition in our Net Promoter Score from our customers. Now in order
componenttext: Thanks for the question, Scott. Yes, there is no question that we improved our in-stock levels and what is terrific is that our customers noticed it. This was an area where we received recognition in our Net Promoter Score from our customers. Now in order to do that, you've heard me just mention this accounts payable to inventory ratio. We did bring our inventories in earlier, and customers are shopping earlier and earlier. So that in retrospect, has turned out to be an excellent decision for us. In addition to that, we have had a significant focus on restocking in our stores, and have made some operational changes in our stores for down stocking. That also -- pay dividends to us during the fourth quarter. In addition, unsure from store, we continue to believe that strategically, ship-from-store will be -- go down in our history at Best Buy as one of the most important strategic decisions that we made because it is allowing us to utilize both our online and our retail inventories to serve the online customers. And it has -- obviously, you've seen the strength of our online growth. You know that business now is over $4 billion. And what ship-from-store is allowing us to do is be able to -- on a consistent basis, make marketing promises to customers about speed of delivery. So to your question on what we said we were going to do this, was there a positive outcome? Clearly, there was a balance sheet investment as related to that accounts payable, the inventory ratio, the answer is yes, we did it. It worked and we're very pleased with it, and we will continue to make additional changes where we believe it's necessary. But Hubert and I, in no way believe that we have solved our in-stock issue.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In my prepared remarks more broadly, I mean on the inventory and in-stock, we believe that operationally from sales proficiency, in particular, we have the opportunity to continue to drive increased performance in our stores and of course, in our onl
componenttext: Yes. In my prepared remarks more broadly, I mean on the inventory and in-stock, we believe that operationally from sales proficiency, in particular, we have the opportunity to continue to drive increased performance in our stores and of course, in our online channel as well. We are not finished. Actually, the -- it fits the first priority I laid out -- we have multiple opportunities there we're very excited about that.

componenttext: That is really difficult to do, particularly at retail. I would -- if I could get that exact number, I would love to have it too, Scott. But it's really difficult to calculate. So no, I'm not ready to put a number out there to say that it drove x basis point of comp. But what I can tell you conversion both in the retail stores and in the online channel was a driver. We had the softness in mobile, and we know that. So we would have been positive without that. And conversion was a significant contributor to those results and obviously, that is one of the hardest things to move. And we feel very good about how we've driven the business.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: And now we'll go to Joseph Feldman with Telsey Group.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask, maybe something a little broader maybe about the consumer and just I know what you're seeing from the consumer or from your market research and studies and surveys of the consumer. Are you seeing any changes, I guess, within categories --
componenttext: I wanted to ask, maybe something a little broader maybe about the consumer and just I know what you're seeing from the consumer or from your market research and studies and surveys of the consumer. Are you seeing any changes, I guess, within categories -- of what consumers are buying? And is there any change in appetite for services? I mean, I know what the service sales rates are. But I guess I'm trying to get at like, has there been a demand change, more broadly speaking, and within economic kind of classification like higher loan and comp?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The U.S. consumer, we could spend the next 30 minutes on that. We are pleased with the main and the spirit of the U.S. consumer, certainly compared to many other geographies outside of the U.S. Demand is there. You see it -- when you see the growth i
componenttext: Yes. The U.S. consumer, we could spend the next 30 minutes on that. We are pleased with the main and the spirit of the U.S. consumer, certainly compared to many other geographies outside of the U.S. Demand is there. You see it -- when you see the growth in appliances, continued growth in appliances, that is a very strong wave. In our category, think we all have to bear in mind that demand is driven by supply. So when there's great exciting innovation, you get that. So most of what we sell is not a basic pavilion need on the part of our customer. So this is an industry where the great supply creates a demand. And we're excited by the technology wave that are coming above and beyond the softness that does existed in phones. From a services standpoint, I would say 2 things: One is, there's clear demand for help on the part of the customer. Now the customer, all of us, don't always want to pay for service. And we will provide and we're providing service today in order to generate more demand. So when we have Magnolia, certain designers coming to your home, that's going to generate demand, but their visit is free, and we're happy to come to your home. Everybody on the call will come into you. Tech-support, however, above and beyond the sales help, is something that customers are happy to pay for, and we are seeing increased demand in this area. So we -- the summary is that we believe we have an opportunity rich environment, and that the key trend made for Best Buy based on these technology waves and the need that customers have for help.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Joe, I'll just add to that from a metric point of view, what can you see? The average order value at Best Buy, again, when you look at what contributed to the outcome of Q4, we saw that again increase. So again, the high-end consumer, I believe, there
componenttext: And Joe, I'll just add to that from a metric point of view, what can you see? The average order value at Best Buy, again, when you look at what contributed to the outcome of Q4, we saw that again increase. So again, the high-end consumer, I believe, there is lot of a noise around the high-end consumer which we, of course, cater to hear at Best Buy Co. And the data, that's what the metrics would tell you about that consumer. Obviously, conversion was up and average order value, both retail and online.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just circle back on the shop-in-shops. Obviously, you've had some of the quite sometime now. And so I just wanted to get update just in terms of how they're performing versus the rest of the house? And then just any indication if you think tha
componenttext: I wanted to just circle back on the shop-in-shops. Obviously, you've had some of the quite sometime now. And so I just wanted to get update just in terms of how they're performing versus the rest of the house? And then just any indication if you think that might be additional shop-in-shops to come?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Anthony. The shop-in-shop with the -- so there's 2 types of shop-in-shop: There's the vendors, the vendors shop-in-shop, and then there's Magnolia Design Centers and Pacific. In general, these enhanced customer experiences have been a key el
componenttext: Good morning, Anthony. The shop-in-shop with the -- so there's 2 types of shop-in-shop: There's the vendors, the vendors shop-in-shop, and then there's Magnolia Design Centers and Pacific. In general, these enhanced customer experiences have been a key element of our transformation in terms of us -- to renovate our stores, increase the customer experience and provide more expertise to our customers, and we're very excited about this. Increasingly, it's difficult to measure because as many of you visit our stores, the shop-in-shop are in many, many of our stores -- so it's really hard to measure scientifically with great precision. However, when you see increased market share, there is no doubt in -- as an example, increased market share in 4K high-end TVs or in appliances, there is no doubt that this has been a key driver of our performance. Looking ahead, there's no doubt that in terms of physical shop-in-shop, there's left to be done, right, because we have high penetration of these shop-in-shops. So I think that looking ahead, we have the opportunity to partner in some cases more deeply with the vendors, in particular, in how we deliver this promise of making it easy to learn about and enjoy the technology. So around help and service and classes, I think there is deeper integration opportunities where the vendors and we are very excited about that as well.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: And our final question will come from Seth Sigman with Credit Suisse.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you help us understand the complexion of that remaining $250 million of Renew Blue savings that you are attacking. And I realize it's early, but any examples of the incremental opportunities that you alluded to earlier and the timing of
componenttext: I was wondering if you help us understand the complexion of that remaining $250 million of Renew Blue savings that you are attacking. And I realize it's early, but any examples of the incremental opportunities that you alluded to earlier and the timing of that?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: From a identification standpoint, we have a robust last of actions that we are going against. And we believe that we will be revealing those overtime to you. We put the $400 million out there, and obviously, you know that we don't communicate anything tha
componenttext: From a identification standpoint, we have a robust last of actions that we are going against. And we believe that we will be revealing those overtime to you. We put the $400 million out there, and obviously, you know that we don't communicate anything that we don't have the exact execution plan behind it to you guys. So as we start developing those plans and may become more crystallized, we will definitely be communicating that. What we wanted to make sure that you guys took away from today's call is that, that $400 million is the bottom of what we believe is possible, and that with these additional opportunities that we've been identifying in the back half of this year, that we continue to believe that there is substantially more opportunity there. So we'll keep you posted as we go. Let's get the $400 billion delivered as well, and then we can talk about more. But there is no doubt that based on some of the looking -- and you guys see that it's very structural, and they're going to come through that product flow and how it comes through Best Buy, it's going to come through our return process, especially on large cube inventory, there is so much opportunity there. There is recovery on inventory that is returned. It's how we handle the movement across the United States with some of our large cube inventory. This comes in many forms. The great news is it comes in many forms. And it is -- there is no lack of opportunity. And I'm going to take 1 more-minute just to lay a backup for why is there this much opportunity at Best Buy. The reason we have these opportunities is because if you think about the growth years for Best Buy, they were opening 50 stores a year and adding $1 billion to $2 billion a year of incremental revenue. And during that time, when you have that kind of growth, trying to keep pace with all of the operational excellence that goes behind that, what you end up doing is creating a large number of triage processes, meaning that while we don't have the system to do this, so we're going to create this workaround and it will work. And then the work around it gets bigger and bigger and bigger as the company continues to grow. But just about the time to get ready to fix it, they've just added another 50 stores another $2 billion worth of revenue and of course, that was the focus back then. Now that the company has reached such scale, these opportunities, these workarounds have become very costly. And that's the opportunity that we have to take them out. But leave it to understand that they are structural, and a lot of change has to happen. And that's why you don't just throw them out there on a list and say, yes, I totally -- I've got to be communicating that we need to give you guys clarity to the road map.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: So maybe, is time -- a few words of closing remarks. Hopefully, you feel that we're quite excited about all our opportunities going forward and proud of our execution could abilities. So I certainly want to again thank our associates who are behind this execution capability and thank you for your continued support. So all of us here, we see some act thank you.
