headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. [ph] Welcome to Best Buy's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for playback and will be available by 11 a.m. Eastern Time t
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. [ph] Welcome to Best Buy's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for playback and will be available by 11 a.m. Eastern Time today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference call over to Mollie O'Brien, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you. Joining me on the call today are Hubert Joly, our Chairman and CEO; and Sharon McCollam, our CAO [ph] and CFO.This morning's conference call must be considered in conjunction with the earnings press release we issued this mo
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you. Joining me on the call today are Hubert Joly, our Chairman and CEO; and Sharon McCollam, our CAO [ph] and CFO.
This morning's conference call must be considered in conjunction with the earnings press release we issued this morning. Today's release and conference call both contain certain non-GAAP financial measures that exclude the impact of certain business events.
These non-GAAP financial measures are provided to facilitate meaningful year-over-year comparisons which should not be considered superior to, as a substitute for and should be read in conjunction with the GAAP financial measures for the period.
[ph] A reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures and an explanation of why these non-GAAP financial measures are useful can be found in this morning's earnings release or our most recent Form 10-K.
[ph] Today's earnings release and conference call also include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
These statements address the financial conditions, results of operations, business initiatives, growth plans, operational investments and prospects of the company and are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from such forward-looking statements.
Please refer to the company's current earnings release and SEC filings for more information on these risks and uncertainties. The company undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances that may arise after the date of this call.
In today's earnings release and conference call, we refer to consumer electronics industry trends.
The consumer electronics industry, as defined and tracked by The NPD Group, includes: TVs; desktop and notebook computers; tablets, not including Kindle; digital imaging; and other categories.
The sales of these products represent approximately 65% of our Domestic [ph] revenue.
It does not include mobile phones, appliances, services, gaming, Apple Watch, movies [indiscernible]. 
I will now turn the call over to Hubert.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mollie, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Let me begin by discussing the announcement we made today regarding Sharon McCollam and Corie Barry. Of course, I first want to thank Sharon for the profound and lasting impact she's
componenttext:
Thank you, Mollie, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. Let me begin by discussing the announcement we made today regarding Sharon McCollam and Corie Barry. Of course, I first want to thank Sharon for the profound and lasting impact she's had on Best Buy and our amazing partnership. As you all know, Sharon came out of retirement in 2012 to help revitalize Best Buy when the company was facing a multifaceted crisis. 3.5 years later, we are in a very different place and are [ph] into the next phase of our journey as a company. And so as she transitions out of her role, Sharon can look forward to spending more time with her husband with a sense of accomplishment and confidence in Best Buy's future. 
Now one of Sharon's legacies is her successor in the CFO role, Corie Barry. Corie is a 16-year veteran of Best Buy and our current Chief Strategic Growth Officer. She's been groomed by Sharon for the CFO role almost since the time Sharon joined the company, and the 2 have collaborated on succession planning with the goal of making this a seamless transition. Over her many years at Best Buy, Corie has had a number of operational and financial roles in the field and at the corporate level, including as Senior Vice President of U.S. Finance and as the interim head of our services business. The board, Sharon and I firmly believe that Corie has the kind of experience, skills and passion for Best Buy that make for the perfect choice for this position. I look forward to working with her in her new role. 
Sharon will remain as CFO until our Annual Shareholder Meeting on June 14, at which time Corie will assume her responsibilities. As part of this transition plan, Sharon will remain with Best Buy in an advisory role until the end of the fiscal year. The duties Sharon has as Chief Administrative Officer will be assumed by several members of our executive team. So let me say once again how grateful we are to Sharon for all that she has done. Her legacy will endure. To Corie, allow me to publicly extend my congratulations. She's been a key player in Best Buy [ph] resurgence, and I'm confident she'll be a great leader for our company in the years ahead.
Altogether, I feel this is a remarkable time for our company. We have an exciting set of assets and opportunities and a very strong team committed to creating great results for all our stakeholders. 
I will now provide an overview of our first quarter performance and an update on our progress against our fiscal 2017 priorities, and I will then turn the call over to Sharon for additional details in our quarterly results and commentary on our financial outlook.
In the first quarter, we delivered better-than-expected Enterprise revenue of $8.44 billion, a 30 basis point improvement in our non-GAAP operating income rate to 2.9% and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.44 versus $0.37 last year. 
In our Domestic business, we delivered better-than-expected, essentially flat comparable sales versus our guidance of a 1% to 2% decline. Contributing to these better-than-expected results was the strong performance in our online channel, which grew 24% in the quarter. And similar to last quarter's strength/trends [ph] from a merchandising perspective, we saw strong year-over-year sales growth in health and wearables, home theater and appliances, offset by continued softness in mobile phones and tablets. 
Industry sales in the NPD-reported categories, which don't reflect mobile phone and appliance sales, declined 1.9%, including the benefit of the shift of the Super Bowl into Q1 fiscal 2017. We also saw significant gains in our Net Promoter Score, which improved more than 600 basis points compared to this time last year, more than 600 basis points. 
In our International business, strong execution and higher sales retention in our Canadian business drove a better-than-expected revenue decline of 1.2% on a constant currency basis despite closing approximately 1/3 or 66 of our large format stores on March 28 of last year. On a reported basis, revenue declined 8% versus our guidance of a 15% to 20% decline, primarily due to a lower-than-expected negative impact from foreign currency and the higher sales retention we are seeing in Canada. So altogether, a strong quarter, and I want to thank our teams across all functions for delivering these results. 
Now I'd like to share highlights of the progress we're making against our fiscal 2017 priorities. As we discussed on our Q4 call, our first priority is to build on our strong industry position and multi-channel capabilities to drive the existing business. This involves implementing a number of initiatives across merchandising, marketing, digital, stores, supply chain, services and customer care. 
In appliances, we leveraged our 176 Pacific Kitchen & Home stores-within-a-store and ongoing market share gains to deliver a 14% increase in revenue and our 22nd consecutive quarter of comp sales growth. As a reminder, we will continue to roll out incremental stores-within-a-store throughout the year. 
In home theater, our market-leading customer experience around 4K and large-screen technologies continue to drive sales growth and market share gains. To continue to build on this experience, we're rolling out 376 new LG experiences in addition to our existing Sony and Samsung experiences. In computing, similar to home theater, our partnership with key vendors and the strengths of our market-leading position have created a superior customer experience that is driving continued market share gains. 
In mobile, we added 25 incremental Verizon and AT&T stores-within-a-store to the 250 we rolled out in the back half of last year. However, the mobile phone category remains challenging as industry demand continues to be soft. Despite this current softness, we continue to believe that over the course of the year, iconic new phone launches can drive renewed growth in this category. 
In our online business, our 24% sales growth was driven by continued improvements to our digital customer experience and enhanced dotcom capabilities, including faster shipping. We continue to focus on improving the shopping journey for our customers, including streamlining the checkout process, providing visibility earlier in the shopping funnel for local store product availability, improving the quality and relevance of product recommendations and increasing search relevancy and accuracy. 
In our retail stores, the level of proficiency and engagement of our associates is continuing to drive meaningful improvement in our Net Promoter Score among both purchasers and nonpurchasers and is contributing to our market share gains. In our services business, we continue to drive improvements in our service quality and increase our Net Promoter Score. 
Year-over-year, our Geek Squad agents also drove more customer interactions across our channels and helped more customers use and enjoy their technology products. As expected, overall services revenue declined during the quarter, due to the carryover effect of the pricing investments we made last September as well as the ongoing reduction of repair [ph] revenue, driven by lower frequency of claims in our extended warranties. 
As a reminder, while at face value, this repair revenue decline appears negative, it is actually financially beneficial because it reflects a reduction of our extended warranty costs. In our international business, we remain focused on our Canadian transformation. As reflected in our revenue performance, customer retention is proving to be higher than expected. 
Looking ahead, our team is focused on continuing to invest in our stores and online channel to improve the customer experience and financial performance, something that is enabled by the consolidation of the 2 brands. 
Our second fiscal 2017 priority is to reduce costs and drive efficiencies throughout the business. Reducing costs is essential for us to be able to fund our investments, build our resilience to product cycles and increase our profitability over time. A key element to achieving this is simplifying and streamlining our core business processes, simultaneously improving the customer and employee experience and driving costs out. This work is well on its way. I want to stress that this is not an isolated short-term cost-reduction program. We're establishing a lean culture focused on systematically eliminating nonquality and defects. This approach requires collaboration across teams and functions, and we're building the organizational capability, mindset and habits necessary to sustain changes. 
As it relates to our Renew Blue Phase 2 cost reduction and gross profit optimization target of $400 million over 3 years, we achieved another $50 million in the first quarter, bringing our current achievements to $200 million. 
The third fiscal 2017 priority is to advance key initiatives to drive future growth and differentiation. While there may be short pressures, we continue to believe we operate in an opportunity-rich environment. We're investing to make it easy for customers to learn about and enjoy the latest technology as they pursue their passions and take care of what is important to them in their lives. 
We see fiscal '17 as a year of exploration and experimentation around creating compelling customer experiences that have the potential to unlock growth. Throughout the year, we will be testing and piloting several concepts around the country, and with our combination of digital, store and in-home assets, we feel we have a great opportunity to address key customer pain points, build stronger ongoing relationships with our customers and unleash growth opportunities. 
So to recap, we delivered a strong first quarter and are reaffirming our fiscal 2017 full year financial outlook that we provided in our Q4 call. That outlook includes approximately flat revenue and non-GAAP operating income with EPS growth driven by share repurchases. 
Although we're reporting better-than-expected results today, we're not raising our full year outlook as the first quarter represents less than 15% of full year earnings. And at this stage, we have no new material information as it relates to product launches throughout the year. 
And now and of course, it's a bit emotional, let me turn the call over to my friend, Sharon McCollam. Sharon, anything you want to share with us this morning?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do, Hubert. Thank you. While I remain in an advisory capacity through the end of the year, this is my last official call as CFO, and as such, I want to take this opportunity to express what an immense privilege it has been to be part of this incred
componenttext:
Yes, I do, Hubert. Thank you. While I remain in an advisory capacity through the end of the year, this is my last official call as CFO, and as such, I want to take this opportunity to express what an immense privilege it has been to be part of this incredible transformation[ph]. With our team of more than 125,000 people, we have worked hand in hand to Renew Blue. And today, as I prepare to step down from my current role to spend more time with my husband and my family, I do so knowing that we have never been as well positioned as we are today to take Best Buy to a new level. 
I'd like to thank my peers, our corporate and field teams and, in particular, my direct reports for their exceptional contribution that have made this possible. I would also like to thank our board and you, our shareholders and analysts, for your confidence and support [ph]. 
Additionally, I want to publicly congratulate Corie. Corie has been my strategic right-hand partner since I joined Best Buy. With her exceptional financial acumen and deep understanding of Best Buy's operations, she has been an influential leader over the financial and cost discipline that have been established across the company over the past several years. She is also a highly respected cross-functional leader and will be an incredible CFO, of whom I could not be more proud or confident. So congratulations, Corie. 
And of course, I want to thank Hubert. You're an extraordinary leader and an inspiring business partner and a friend. I will be forever grateful to have had the opportunity to share this journey with you and our entire Best Buy family.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sharon. We owe you so much. Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you, Sharon. We owe you so much. Thank you.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hubert. Okay, so now let's talk about our Q1 results. Before I talk about these results versus last year, I'd like to discuss them versus the expectations we shared with you on our Q4 call. Enterprise revenue of $8.44 billion exceeded our exp
componenttext:
Thank you, Hubert. Okay, so now let's talk about our Q1 results. 
Before I talk about these results versus last year, I'd like to discuss them versus the expectations we shared with you on our Q4 call. Enterprise revenue of $8.44 billion exceeded our expectations, driven equally by the outperformance of our Domestic and International businesses. Non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.44 also exceeded our expectations, primarily due to the flow-through of higher revenue. Additionally, a lower effective income tax rate contributed to an incremental $0.01 of EPS versus our expectations. 
I will now talk about our Q1 results versus last year. On a constant currency basis, Enterprise revenue declined 0.8% to $8.44 billion, primarily due to the impact of Domestic and Canadian store closures. On a reported basis, Enterprise revenue declined 1.3%, reflecting approximately 55 basis points of negative foreign currency impact. Enterprise non-GAAP diluted EPS increased $0.07 or 19% to $0.44. This increase was primarily driven by Canada, which is lapping the disruptive impact from the brand consolidation last year and a $0.04 per share benefit from share repurchases. These increases were partially offset by the negative impact of lower revenue in the Domestic segment and a higher non-GAAP effective income tax rate. 
In our Domestic segment, revenue decreased a less-than-expected 0.8% to $7.8 billion. This decrease was primarily driven by the loss of revenue from 13 large format and 24 Best Buy Mobile store closures. Comparable sales were essentially flat. From a merchandising perspective, comparable sales growth in health and wearables, home theater, major appliances and computing was offset by declines in mobile phones, tablets and gaming. As expected, television sales related to the shift of the Super Bowl into Q1 '17 positively impacted the Domestic segment by approximately 70 basis points. 
In services, comparable revenue declined 10.7% due to investments in services pricing and the ongoing reduction of repair revenue, driven by lower frequency of claims on extended warranties. Domestic comparable online revenue increased 23.9% to $832 million, primarily due to higher conversion rates and increased traffic. As a percentage of total Domestic revenue, online revenue increased 210 basis points to 10.6% versus 8.5% last year. 
In our International segment, on a constant currency basis, revenue declined 1.2% to $614 million due primarily to closed stores in Canada. On a reported basis, International revenue declined 8.1%, reflecting approximately 690 basis points of negative foreign currency impacts. 
Turning now to gross profit. The Enterprise non-GAAP gross profit rate increased 30 basis points to 23.2%. The Domestic non-GAAP gross profit rate increased 10 basis points to 23%, primarily due to a prior year reserve on non-iconic phone inventory, which did not recur this year and improved rates, primarily driven by our more disciplined promotional strategy across product categories. These increases were partially offset by our investment in service pricing. 
The International non-GAAP gross profit rate increased 310 basis points to 25.9%, primarily driven by a higher year-over-year gross profit rate in Canada as we lapped [ph] the significant disruption and corresponding increase promotional activity related to the brand consolidation in Q1 fiscal '16, and we received a higher periodic profit sharing payment in our services business. 
Now turning to SG&A. Enterprise-level non-GAAP SG&A was $1.7 billion or 20.3% of revenue, a decrease of $24 million or flat on a rate basis. Domestic non-GAAP SG&A was $1.56 billion or 19.9% of revenue, which was flat year-over-year as investments in the business were offset by the flow-through of Renew Blue Phase 2 cost reductions. 
From a rate perspective, non-GAAP SG&A increased 10 basis points, primarily driven by year-over-year sales deleverage. International non-GAAP SG&A was $156 million or 25.4% of revenue, a decrease of $23 million or 140 basis points. This decrease was primarily driven by the elimination of expenses associated with the Canadian brand consolidation and the positive impact of foreign exchange rates. 
I'll now discuss our fiscal 2017 and Q2 '17 outlook. As Hubert said, from a financial outlook perspective, we are reaffirming our expectations of approximately flat revenue and flat non-GAAP operating income for the full year, including lapping the significant periodic profit sharing benefits from our services plan portfolio that we earned in fiscal '16. A key element to achieve this will be the delivery of our cost reduction and gross profit optimization initiatives. Based on current industry dynamics and how we see the various product cycles playing out, we are expecting slight declines in revenue in the first half followed by growth in the back half. 
As we discussed on our last earnings call, we recognize this will be challenging without a stronger mobile cycle and improvements in the NPD-reported categories overall. I would now like to talk about our Q2 financial guidance. For Q2, we are expecting Enterprise revenue in the range of $8.35 billion to $8.45 billion, and both Enterprise and Domestic comparable sales of approximately flat. We expect International revenues to decline approximately 5% to 10% on a reported basis but to be flat on a constant currency basis. 
We expect our Q2 non-GAAP diluted earnings per share to be in the range of $0.38 to $0.42, assuming a diluted weighted average share count of approximately 325 million and a non-GAAP effective income tax rate in the range of 36% to 36.5%. In line with our original expectations, there are 2 factors impacting our Q2 year-over-year non-GAAP EPS guidance. 
First, we are expecting an approximate $0.03 net negative impact from the lapping of the periodic service profit sharing payment from our services plan portfolio that we received in the second quarter of last year. 
Second, we are expecting an approximate $0.06 negative impact from the carryover of last September's services pricing investment. In addition, in digital imaging, we are now expecting an approximate $0.03 to $0.04 negative impact due to the April 2016 earthquake in Japan, which is impacting inventory availability in this high-margin category. 
Combined, these are putting $0.12 to $0.13 of pressure on Q2 fiscal '17, which will be partially offset by approximate $0.04 benefit from share repurchases. 
I would now like to turn the call over to the operator for questions.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Matt McClintock with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Matt McClintock with Barclays.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Best of luck, Sharon. Really, we're going to miss you. I was wondering if we could talk about the online growth rate for the quarter. I think that's the best growth rate you guys have achieved in 2 years, and it's interesting because it's coming at a time
componenttext: Best of luck, Sharon. Really, we're going to miss you. I was wondering if we could talk about the online growth rate for the quarter. I think that's the best growth rate you guys have achieved in 2 years, and it's interesting because it's coming at a time that we're seeing other retailers, their growth rates decelerate and your growth rate online is accelerating. Can you maybe talk a little bit more in detail on what's going on in that business specifically?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- thank you, Matt, and good morning. We are very focused on the digital experience for a couple of reasons. One is that the e-commerce channel is growing; and two, it's impacting the entire business. Specifically to the growth rate in e-commerce,
componenttext: Yes, we -- thank you, Matt, and good morning. We are very focused on the digital experience for a couple of reasons. One is that the e-commerce channel is growing; and two, it's impacting the entire business. Specifically to the growth rate in e-commerce, the 24% growth rate is a very good number. It's really the cumulative effective of the investments we've been making in the last 3 [ph] years that are impacting the customer experience. We're shipping faster. That's a very important point. But if you go on the site, and I hope all of you are regular shoppers on the site, 3 years ago, I would have characterized our site as being clunky. Today, there's all sorts of good surprises as you shop, as you research, as you look for information about the products. We've made improvements in the quarter on the checkout process. So it's a lot of small changes, both on the site itself and, of course, the mobile experience has been investing significantly. So really, [ph] a combination of what's happening on the site, the shipping experience. We've improved in-store pick up, the experience in the stores. So it's an all out efforts [ph] really the cumulative impact of the investments and improvements we've been making over the last 3 years.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: And our next question is from Scott Mushkin with Wolfe Research.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations to Corie, and good luck, Sharon. I guess I wanted to go the same route with the e-commerce and just as it grows -- and I'm actually on your website right now and clearly, you guys have done a lot of work. How does it fit into the stores? I
componenttext: Congratulations to Corie, and good luck, Sharon. I guess I wanted to go the same route with the e-commerce and just as it grows -- and I'm actually on your website right now and clearly, you guys have done a lot of work. How does it fit into the stores? In other words, how does it fit into the asset base and your thought process around the asset base if the growth in e-commerce continues at such a rapid clip? Does it make you think that maybe some further store closures would be on the table or no?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you for the question. The -- we think of the company as a company that is there to provide a great experience for the customer across all channels. And increasingly, it will be difficult to measure the contribution of each channel because again,
componenttext: So thank you for the question. The -- we think of the company as a company that is there to provide a great experience for the customer across all channels. And increasingly, it will be difficult to measure the contribution of each channel because again, and you guys all know this, the shopping journey starts online, may then be completed online or in the stores. There's a journey to the store. If you're going to buy a 4K TV, the only way to see the quality of the picture and ask questions is really in the store, but then the transaction may be completed in the store or online. So our overall goal as a company, frankly, is to accelerate the total revenue growth from the customers, existing customers and new customers, so that we can create shareholder value and value for all of the stakeholders. In a context where revenue, total revenue would be flat, then yes, it would put pressure on the economics of the business. As you know, from a store portfolio standpoint, since the beginning of the Renew Blue journey, we've said that we would, over time, optimize the store footprint, and we are doing this on an ongoing basis, and we're ready to continue to do that. But I would say the overriding objective is to accelerate the growth so that it can lift all boats in our journey. And Sharon, anything you'd like to add to this?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Hubert. I also want to point out the strategic portfolio that we have of stores because about 1/3 of our customers still today actually choose to pick their orders up in our stores. So this alignment between the online channel and the ability to let
componenttext: Yes, Hubert. I also want to point out the strategic portfolio that we have of stores because about 1/3 of our customers still today actually choose to pick their orders up in our stores. So this alignment between the online channel and the ability to let the customer receive their product either through the mail or in our store, but it's more importantly about how they choose to receive it. Additionally, our stores are the magic that go behind our ship-from-store and our delivery times which, as you know, we've created a North Star, which is Amazon Prime. And with that, our stores are essential to that process. So the store portfolio, while to Hubert's point we have rationalized the portfolio, and we'll continue to do so, the stores are also really working hard on a concept, which we talked about for a long time, which is our value add. And the stores have a critical role in the growth, not only of our store channel, but the e-comm channel. And today, the number of orders that are actually being placed in our stores online and that capability, as Hubert talked about capabilities that we've been building, we have been making it easier and easier for us to convert a customer where there may be something that may not be in the store and they want it in the stores, our Blue Shirts are doing a remarkable job of converting that order in the store, which turns into an online order. So from a portfolio standpoint, I think our store portfolio is extremely strategic, and we'll continue to rationalize it. But quite frankly, it just continues to lift its performance, and that's great news for us.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question is from Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sharon, all the best to you, of course. My question relates to wireless. If you could talk about within that mobile and computing line item, which was -- picked up a little bit of ground versus Q4, what you saw specifically for the wireless trend in Q1 re
componenttext: Sharon, all the best to you, of course. My question relates to wireless. If you could talk about within that mobile and computing line item, which was -- picked up a little bit of ground versus Q4, what you saw specifically for the wireless trend in Q1 relative to the Q4 decline that you had noted.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, the wireless industry market, and there is some public information around this, has continued to be quite soft in the quarter as we anniversary a more iconic launch the previous year. So it continued to be soft, and we continue to believe that
componenttext: Yes, Matt, the wireless industry market, and there is some public information around this, has continued to be quite soft in the quarter as we anniversary a more iconic launch the previous year. So it continued to be soft, and we continue to believe that significant launches in the back half of the year can revert the trend. So really very consistent pattern compared to the previous quarter, to be specifically answering your question.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just adding to that -- Matt, adding to that, it is, I think, important to note though that when there were some new product launches in the quarter, we did see an improvement in performance. And so that gives us confidence that as new things -- I don'
componenttext: And just adding to that -- Matt, adding to that, it is, I think, important to note though that when there were some new product launches in the quarter, we did see an improvement in performance. And so that gives us confidence that as new things -- I don't want to exaggerate that, but as new things come to market, we do -- we have seen a slight improvement in that -- in the back half of the quarter.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to the extent that your same-store sales declined in Domestic, computing and mobile moderated to 3.5 from 6.5 was that then improvement -- was that -- sorry, was that improvement then in computing as opposed to wireless?
componenttext: And to the extent that your same-store sales declined in Domestic, computing and mobile moderated to 3.5 from 6.5 was that then improvement -- was that -- sorry, was that improvement then in computing as opposed to wireless?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So computing, we have a very strong position in computing. We've -- in partnership with key vendors, we've built a superior customer experience, where we replace where to shop for our computer. So we're gaining share, and we've accelerated our moment
componenttext: Yes. So computing, we have a very strong position in computing. We've -- in partnership with key vendors, we've built a superior customer experience, where we replace where to shop for our computer. So we're gaining share, and we've accelerated our momentum in the quarter previous -- compared to the previous quarter, absolutely.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Greg Melich with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Greg Melich with Evercore ISI.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to follow up on the SG&A comments and comments, Hubert and Sharon, you guys talked about taking out cost to increase investment. So look at that number if you just looked at Domestic SG&A, which is flat, I guess, year-over-year, how much of that wa
componenttext: Wanted to follow up on the SG&A comments and comments, Hubert and Sharon, you guys talked about taking out cost to increase investment. So look at that number if you just looked at Domestic SG&A, which is flat, I guess, year-over-year, how much of that was cost out? And how much of that was investment? And if we thought about it going forward, is the first quarter sort of typical if you think about the rest of the year in terms of that investment?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so thank you for your question. Strategically, we're very -- we have been very focused, and we'll continue to be very focused on driving efficiencies throughout the business so as to -- as we said, fund the investments and increase our resilience to
componenttext: Yes, so thank you for your question. Strategically, we're very -- we have been very focused, and we'll continue to be very focused on driving efficiencies throughout the business so as to -- as we said, fund the investments and increase our resilience to cycles and over time, improve our profitability. Quarter-to-quarter, things will fluctuate a little bit based on variable compensation. Marketing, that fluctuates a little bit. In the first quarter, we're very proud of the cost reductions we've made that have offset the investments. So for the full year, that's the pattern we have thought about, and that we'll continue to drive in. We're pacing ourselves. It's a discipline that we have with pacing the investments based on the cost reductions. Sharon, anything you'd like to add?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Hubert. So and as you just, remember that as you look towards Q2, we are expecting to see a similar SG&A outcome dollar decline in Q2 as well. Again, that will be investments being offset by the recognition of our Renew Blue Phase 2 cost reductions.
componenttext: Yes, Hubert. So and as you just, remember that as you look towards Q2, we are expecting to see a similar SG&A outcome dollar decline in Q2 as well. Again, that will be investments being offset by the recognition of our Renew Blue Phase 2 cost reductions. But sequentially, Q2 is always a bigger SG&A quarter for us because our advertising kicks in for back to school. So when you're looking at it sequentially quarter-to-quarter, much better to take a look at because we do have seasonality in the SG&A, best to look at it year-over-year. But in the Q2 outlook, we're anticipating that SG&A will at the Enterprise level, it's going to look very similar to Q1 on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sharon, best wishes to you, and Corie, congratulations. Wanted to ask a question about International and was just hoping for an update on how things are progressing in Canada. What kind of transfer rate you've been seeing from the brand consolidation, and
componenttext: Sharon, best wishes to you, and Corie, congratulations. Wanted to ask a question about International and was just hoping for an update on how things are progressing in Canada. What kind of transfer rate you've been seeing from the brand consolidation, and what sort of operating income and EPS benefit you're looking forward to this year.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you for the question. We're very excited about the changes we've made in Canada. It's going to take a while before things settle because year-over-year comparisons are going to be a bit difficult to assess. Last year, there was a lot of disrupt
componenttext: Yes. Thank you for the question. We're very excited about the changes we've made in Canada. It's going to take a while before things settle because year-over-year comparisons are going to be a bit difficult to assess. Last year, there was a lot of disruptions in Q1, Q2 and going into Q3 still. But altogether, the decision to consolidate the 2 brands was very fundamental to our future. As you remember, where these 2 brands often times, 2 stores in the same parking lot made it difficult for us to invest in the stores because many of them were some critical mass, and so we've unlocked that. The retention has been materially better than expected and much better than what we're seeing in the U.S. And I say strong capability, probably the reflection on our strong leadership position in the market and the combination of higher retention and closing stores, of course, will have a positive impact on the profitability. This is going to be a smaller, more profitable business for us. But above and beyond the short-term profit improvement, the long-term commitment is now that we've simplified the business is the ability that we have to invest in the customer experience online, in the stores and in the home. So that's what we said. I don't know that we've given specific numbers on the retention, but it's materially better. We can almost do the math because Canada is the bulk of the International business. We've given you the dates at which we closed the stores, the number also. You can almost do the math. It's a pretty significant retention. So we're very happy about it.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brad, just take a look at the -- on a reported basis, the revenue on our constant currency basis just declined a little over 1%. And obviously, at the end of March last year, we closed 1/3 of our stores, about 60-plus stores. So when you look at that
componenttext: Yes, Brad, just take a look at the -- on a reported basis, the revenue on our constant currency basis just declined a little over 1%. And obviously, at the end of March last year, we closed 1/3 of our stores, about 60-plus stores. So when you look at that, you can see at the retention is pretty exceptional, and the execution of that team has been remarkable.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of course, it looks like it's shaping up to be nice contributor here this year. Any reason that the pace of benefit that we saw in the first quarter may not continue at this rate going forward?
componenttext: Of course, it looks like it's shaping up to be nice contributor here this year. Any reason that the pace of benefit that we saw in the first quarter may not continue at this rate going forward?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely because the -- as I said in the first part of my response, the year-over-year comparison is going to be very muddy for the few quarters. Think about last quarter, we closed stores in the middle of the quarter. We actually closed a Future S
componenttext: Yes, absolutely because the -- as I said in the first part of my response, the year-over-year comparison is going to be very muddy for the few quarters. Think about last quarter, we closed stores in the middle of the quarter. We actually closed a Future Shop for a full week, the Future Shop that continued, we closed them for a full week to retrain the associates. For several months, the Future Shop stores even though we have announced that we are closing Future Shop, the Future Shop stores still look like Future Shop stores. It took us well into the summer to rebrand them as Best Buy stores. So as you can imagine, the Canadian customer was very confused but, then there was some extraordinary expenses last year as we were going through the transition, and so it's really difficult to -- you should not extrapolate. Let me be very clear. The Q1 results and assume that kind of improvement is going to be sustained. We fully expect it's going to be better, but it's going to be rocky comparisons in the first few quarters.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Brad, as a reminder, we talked about when we did the Canadian brand consolidation, which is actually exciting, we have been testing into some work in our stores. We had talked about there would be a capital investment this year that was when we gave
componenttext: And, Brad, as a reminder, we talked about when we did the Canadian brand consolidation, which is actually exciting, we have been testing into some work in our stores. We had talked about there would be a capital investment this year that was when we gave our outlook on CapEx for this year. There was a little more CapEx because we were going to do more work in Canada. We've been doing it very methodically, testing, seeing what works, rolling it very judiciously. And what Hubert is speaking to as we work through the year is there are going to be periods especially before holiday while -- where we will be making some of those investments, and so it will be some puts and takes in the next couple of quarters around Canada. But there is no question that we are expecting a improvement in their performance.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Lasser with UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Lasser with UBS.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Best of luck, Sharon, and congratulations, Corie. Hubert, the spread between Best Buy's Domestic same-store sales, and the change in the category as measured by NPD compressed a bit this quarter, suggesting that your share gains moderated a bit. Why do yo
componenttext: Best of luck, Sharon, and congratulations, Corie. Hubert, the spread between Best Buy's Domestic same-store sales, and the change in the category as measured by NPD compressed a bit this quarter, suggesting that your share gains moderated a bit. Why do you think that was? And is it right to expect that this tighter spread from the first quarter will persist moving forward? Or might it even compressed a bit further from here?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- and I appreciate it's hard to track because what we have when we report our earnings is NPD, and NPD for us is a meaningful part of the categories we sell. It's about 60% plus, but it excludes appliances and phones, and so while at the NPD categ
componenttext: So the -- and I appreciate it's hard to track because what we have when we report our earnings is NPD, and NPD for us is a meaningful part of the categories we sell. It's about 60% plus, but it excludes appliances and phones, and so while at the NPD categories improved, and bear in mind that there's the Super Bowl that's not quite 1.9 percentage probably, maybe between 2.5% and 3% a decline of NPD when normalizing for the Super Bowl. You have the very material decline in phones, and so we -- I estimate that we are continuing to gain share at pretty consistent pattern. We've not seen any material change there. Of course, it varies by category. We think that the entire strategy of the company over the last 3 years on top of the cost reductions we've made is the very systematic and significant improvements in the customer experience across all touch points, across all channels that are resulting in us gaining share and being able to beat the revenue for this quarter. So no material change, Michael. We will continue to monitor this, but the -- but bear in mind, the softness in mobile.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Chris Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Chris Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sharon, first off, congratulations on how much you contributed to Best Buy turnaround, and congratulations, Corie, as well. So just following up on that question, can you talk about share in the TV category? And yes, I think a lot of retailers talked abou
componenttext: Sharon, first off, congratulations on how much you contributed to Best Buy turnaround, and congratulations, Corie, as well. So just following up on that question, can you talk about share in the TV category? And yes, I think a lot of retailers talked about deceleration in the April, May time frame. It doesn't seem like that actually happened to you because ex Super Bowl shift, you're still guiding to about the same comp in the second quarter. So what changed in the business during that time frame? Was that PC getting better? Was that mobile picking up a little bit more there?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Chris, in the quarter, I think compared to our expectations, computing was better. No doubt about this. Again the results of our partnerships with the key vendors and great customer experience across all of the touch points with computing was better, a
componenttext: So Chris, in the quarter, I think compared to our expectations, computing was better. No doubt about this. Again the results of our partnerships with the key vendors and great customer experience across all of the touch points with computing was better, and phones was softer. The week-to-week, month-to-month variations, I'm not going to go there because it is always a this or that, but on a quarterly basis, yes, you've heard our Q2 guidance very consistent with Q1, and so we'll continue to monitor this. One element of philosophy for the company is that there may be fluctuations in the customer buying intentions, mood and so forth. We know what we can control and the focus on execution, our ability to control what we can control is a key mantra of the company across all touch points. And believe me, while we're proud of what we've done, there's so much more to do across all channels in driving our performance. So we'll continue to be focused on that. When we manage our teams, we're not interested in excuses of any sort. It's all about the performance they can drive.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the TV share question?
componenttext: And then on the TV share question?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we gained -- we did gain share in television and would expect to based on the premium experience, but we have to offer the customer in our store -- we continue with the tremendous partnerships that we have with Samsung and Sony and LG, et cetera. Wit
componenttext: Yes, we gained -- we did gain share in television and would expect to based on the premium experience, but we have to offer the customer in our store -- we continue with the tremendous partnerships that we have with Samsung and Sony and LG, et cetera. With those partnerships, we have an exceptional experience in our stores. These are still new technologies for all the customers that are buying new 4K TVs, and we are continuing to offer the customer a very, very strong experience, and I think that's differentiating us from others. I also think that as you're looking at these weeks and months of industry data, including even the NPD data, the Super Bowl shift is really a big shift for all of us. So I think that the conversation gets a little sloppy because of the Super Bowl shift. So just that's just a broad statement for all -- when you're interpreting all the results that are coming out, I think that is an issue.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: From a -- and let me add one word on TVs. Looking ahead, I think everybody would expect that there's product cycles, and Best Buy can still do particularly well in the first part of the -- of any product cycle, and then as the technology gets more mass, t
componenttext: From a -- and let me add one word on TVs. Looking ahead, I think everybody would expect that there's product cycles, and Best Buy can still do particularly well in the first part of the -- of any product cycle, and then as the technology gets more mass, then it gets into more places. And the -- at some points, the growth in TVs will slow down. It's not revert and then at some point, we would expect to not be able to hold the kind of great share we've had. We're not surrendering in advance. But as investors, you guys have been around. You know that this is the kind of thing that happen. So when it happens, don't be surprised.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on Renew Blue 2. I think you're now at $200 million of savings, about halfway to that $400 million goal. It seems like it's going well and maybe faster than you've expected, and you've mentioned there's some upside. Are there any large items th
componenttext: A question on Renew Blue 2. I think you're now at $200 million of savings, about halfway to that $400 million goal. It seems like it's going well and maybe faster than you've expected, and you've mentioned there's some upside. Are there any large items that's on a future list that is not part of that bucket yet that you haven't been able to touch because you're waiting for other capabilities to fall into place? Just thinking about ways you can get upside to those numbers.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- our pattern in the last 3 years has been to increase the number when we've achieved a number. Remember, when we had announced $725 million, we increased it to $1 billion when we had achieved the $725 million. So we fully expect to continue tha
componenttext: Yes. The -- our pattern in the last 3 years has been to increase the number when we've achieved a number. Remember, when we had announced $725 million, we increased it to $1 billion when we had achieved the $725 million. So we fully expect to continue that pattern. This said, the -- in this new phase, I think this is a very exciting new phase. This notion of ongoing process improvements and lean approach I think is very exciting because it simultaneously improve the employee experience, the customer experience and the cost structure. The buckets we're attacking have a lot to do with our, we call this overall product flow integrated supply chain, call it as you would like, which of course, includes the work we still have to do on returns, replacements our damages and end of life and so forth. The -- while we have a pattern of humbly looking at one step at a time, the overall cost structure there and process improvement opportunities give us a lot of optimism around what can be done. So the teams are very busy at work. They're very methodical, and we'll keep you updated. We're not going to give a number today, but we are confident that we'll be able to have a gift that keeps giving over many years coming from that broad areas.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sharon, congrats again, and obviously, Corie, congrats to you as well. I just want to follow-up on one of the last questions about the near-term outlook. You just did flat comps basically with 70 basis point benefit from the Super Bowl. You're guiding to
componenttext: Sharon, congrats again, and obviously, Corie, congrats to you as well. I just want to follow-up on one of the last questions about the near-term outlook. You just did flat comps basically with 70 basis point benefit from the Super Bowl. You're guiding to flat comps in Q2, so that would imply that something is getting better, and you have a pretty difficult comparison in that quarter. So any more color on how you're thinking about that, and what gives you confidence in that underlying trend?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the categories that we expect to continue to do well are those that we've mentioned, health and wearables or home theater and appliances, where we have a strong continued track record, offset by phones and tablets, and we have referenced in t
componenttext: Yes. I think the categories that we expect to continue to do well are those that we've mentioned, health and wearables or home theater and appliances, where we have a strong continued track record, offset by phones and tablets, and we have referenced in the digital imaging piece. Factor the variations you are talking about from 1 quarter to the other are pretty small. So this is our team's best estimates based on the improvement of the customer experience, the promotional calendar, the momentum in the various product categories and then we'll focus on deliver that. No massive shift. It's a lot of small moving pieces that equate to this aggregate number, which is not a huge variation again that even if you take the Super Bowl piece, it's less than 100 basis points. So it's really small, but we're on it.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, that's helpful. And just one follow-up question about the mobile category specifically how you're thinking about Best Buy Mobile standalone stores. So I realize there some optimism about the second half outlook here and some of the broader dri
componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's helpful. And just one follow-up question about the mobile category specifically how you're thinking about Best Buy Mobile standalone stores. So I realize there some optimism about the second half outlook here and some of the broader drivers, but the growth of the category has been a little bit more challenged. Is there any more color you can provide on how those Best Buy mobile standalone stores have performed even just in relative terms from a profit perspective. And if there's an opportunity maybe accelerate some of the closings? I think you still have 350 or so stores.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: You want to take that, Sharon?
componenttext: You want to take that, Sharon?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'd be happy to. So our Best Buy Mobile stores actually play a very strategic marketing role for us at Best Buy, and we're going to have cycles in mobile, ups and downs. These are obviously our smaller stores. But these teams in our mobile stores ha
componenttext: Sure, I'd be happy to. So our Best Buy Mobile stores actually play a very strategic marketing role for us at Best Buy, and we're going to have cycles in mobile, ups and downs. These are obviously our smaller stores. But these teams in our mobile stores have some of the highest NPS scores in the entire mobile business because of the specialty nature of how we can serve our customers in those stores. They also tend to fit in malls versus our big-box stores, which do not fit in malls. So they play a very interesting, strategic marketing role. Now we have said for the last several years that when you're thinking about in modeling our business, you really need to model the big boxes. The mobile stores, our goal for the mobile store is to make them a powerful marketing customer service vehicle, a convenience play for our customers. But as far as increases in profits over the years, et cetera, that is not a modeling that we're doing and wouldn't certainly wouldn't want you guys to do that. Always be plus or minus a little, but they're quite small. As far as the rationalization, we have closed some of the stores, again very similar to our view on the big-box stores. We want to continue to offer to our customers these retail locations where it makes sense. When a store doesn't make sense, you guys know we have not been shy about closing a few here and there. But at this point, there is no major plan out there to further rationalize that portfolio. I don't about you guys, but I love free marketing, and the fact that they pay be for themselves and offer our customers such an exceptional experience is a pretty compelling reason to let the fleet run.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016

componenttext: Scot Ciccarelli. Can you provide any more color on the TV business, namely, what are you seeing today in terms of velocity versus ASP compression? And then how do you expect that to play out in the second half?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- you do have ASP compression year-over-year, which makes it -- makes 4K large-screen TVs very exciting to buy and help with the penetration. So that's, of course, the characteristics of our business, and it's quite material to NPD. The decline
componenttext: Yes. The -- you do have ASP compression year-over-year, which makes it -- makes 4K large-screen TVs very exciting to buy and help with the penetration. So that's, of course, the characteristics of our business, and it's quite material to NPD. The decline for 4K average selling prices is approximately 30% during the period we've had. So that's very material. We expect this will continue in the back half and so forth, which will make the category very exciting from consumer standpoint, and again we'll start to bring this to more mass status. We remain very confident in the amazing customer experience that we've built, both online but notably in our stores. If you want to buy 4K TV, we are the place to do this. Our teams are ready.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016

componenttext: Just a clarification there, Hubert. If we continue to see ASP declines that we are and presumably, there tends to be some even further acceleration just from a seasonal standpoint, what are we thinking about in terms of actual revenue from the TV category in terms of unit velocity, unit growth enough to offset the ASP declines? Or are we again at that point as you referenced earlier, TV isn't necessarily growing at that point?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, of course, looking into the back half of the year last year we really had some pretty significant ASP declines, but to your point with my comment earlier, there will be it's hards to call exactly when the ASP decline will, in fact, impact the overall
componenttext: Yes, of course, looking into the back half of the year last year we really had some pretty significant ASP declines, but to your point with my comment earlier, there will be it's hards to call exactly when the ASP decline will, in fact, impact the overall revenue in the industry. So this is a big category for us. We're doing well. There will be point where we should expect to see that.

componenttext: So 2 questions asked at the same time. One, just on product category. I know it's early but just wondering your thoughts on virtual reality. And then, I guess, an unrelated but also question anyway is buybacks a little bit lower than, of course, in the fourth quarter, but it looks like if we look at last year, you also did not buy a lot of shares in the first quarter. So do we expect a similar type pattern to play out, not a lot of buybacks in the first quarter and then accelerating through the year?

componenttext: Yes, virtual reality's a very exciting technology. I bet you have all have seen that we were exclusive place you could try the oculus in our stores. So a lot of excitement there. The impact on the business this year is going to be very marginal. So I think exciting from a consumer and PR standpoint, very small at this point, from a revenue standpoint. Sharon, on the buyback, why didn't we buy more shares in first quarter?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hubert, yes. It really is the way our pattern has been since we've been buying shares back. Remember, that we -- because of year-end earnings releases, there's a period in the middle of the first quarter where we are out of the market until we get our inf
componenttext: Hubert, yes. It really is the way our pattern has been since we've been buying shares back. Remember, that we -- because of year-end earnings releases, there's a period in the middle of the first quarter where we are out of the market until we get our information out there. So we're always going to be a little bit lower, probably in the first quarter. You guys can probably expect that because that'll always probably be the case. And then, of course, we are absolutely committed to our $1 billion repurchase over the next couple of years. So we are all in on that.

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I will add my congratulations to Sharon and Corie, the long list of congratulations. In our store checks, we see the Blue Shirts very engaged and consultative over the last quarter or 2, not that they weren't before but sort of reaching a new level. A
componenttext: And I will add my congratulations to Sharon and Corie, the long list of congratulations. In our store checks, we see the Blue Shirts very engaged and consultative over the last quarter or 2, not that they weren't before but sort of reaching a new level. And I know you've been working on that. But could you talk about how that focus works at the store level? Could you talk about how we should think about that impacting the business. Is it building steam? Or is there some sort of lap we should understand in that emphasis?

headline: Best Buy Co., Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, thank you so much for your comments. This will go to the heart of all of our Blue Shirts. The fact that we're telling them that we're seeing it is great. The fact that you're seeing it is just terrific, and I want to publicly again recognize their
componenttext:
David, thank you so much for your comments. This will go to the heart of all of our Blue Shirts. The fact that we're telling them that we're seeing it is great. The fact that you're seeing it is just terrific, and I want to publicly again recognize their work. The work on developing the engagements and proficiency in the stores has been a key area for us, and I have to give credit where credit is due to Sheri Barnard and her team across the country in driving that. What is the form that it takes is your question. It's a number of things. The most impressive thing is that the individual level, the philosophy is that the performance of Best Buy is really the sum of the individual performance of each individual associate. The way you lift the performance of Best Buy is by getting more of the associates to be very proficient, very engaged and to achieve their individual sales targets. As you know, we're not commissioned, but we're driving performance. The form it takes in the stores is through daily coaching. Every morning, when you check in as an associate, you spend time with your supervisor looking at the results and getting a one-on-one, and it's absolutely world-class. Coaching about how you can get better at your job even though associates looking at the performance, we look at what are the things they we can get better, they can get some ideas from their Manager and then check in during the day and then check in at the end of the day. It's a systematic approach. Now on top of that, we're increasingly focused on lifting the product knowledge because proficiency is selling skills and product knowledge. We're moving to certify the associates and raising the bar in terms of what's expected. All of the executive team at Best Buy is certified to sell 4K TV and high-end networking equipment, showing that it's part of their job. If the bosses cannot do the job, then it's not a good company. So there is a -- of course, it goes to all of associates, which really beautiful to see. We believe there is a lot more room to drive performance on that basis. If we look at the percentage of our team, the percentage of associates who are achieving individual targets, we see a lot of room for improvement, and that's continued focus. So the way it manifests itself is that a store gets the traffic it gets. That's not within essentially control of store, but they're focused on it we call value add, which is difference between traffic and then the comp stores in the stores and with the given traffic to get different results, and so with the same amount of payroll, you can get different results. So we think that this is another gift that will keep giving and truly a remarkable set of accomplishment so far. Sheri, congratulations for your work, but beyond Sheri, well done to the entire Best Buy team across their stores. Couldn't be more proud.
So I need to conclude the call. I want to thank all of you for joining us today. Again, a very strong quarter. Again, I want to congratulate all of our teams. We are, as you can feel, we are very excited to have the opportunity continue to work on our key priorities and with the opportunities that are related to that. I want to join everybody, of course, on the call in congratulating Sharon and Corie. I know Corie is very much looking forward to meeting all of you and working with all of you. I know Sharon is very much looking forward to introducing -- as a reminder, Sharon is not going away. She's going to be here until the end of the year in advisory role. She introduced Corie to each of the investors and analysts and work with Corie to make this an incredibly seamless transition. It's one of -- going to be one of Sharon's legacy -- her legacies to have successfully onboarded, chosen and onboarded and groomed and onboarded Corie. So very exciting time ahead. Thank you so much for your attention. You all have a great day.
